entry.title: Combined summary - Comments on BOLT#11
entry.summary: The discussion in this context revolves around the use of payment request descriptions in Lightning Network transactions. There are various proposals and suggestions made by different developers regarding the implementation of descriptions. Jonathan Underwood has suggested hiding text under certain conditions in the description and adding an "extra data" tag. Rusty Russell, on the other hand, suggests that HTLC.me should have a description entry field in their "Request Payment" form to avoid violating spec. The use of UTF-8 encoding for descriptions in Bitcoin transactions is also discussed, with suggestions for improvement such as setting a max length for invoices and adding UTF-8 support.A developer has implemented BOLT11 and shared it on Github. Suggestions for improvement include setting a max length for invoices and adding UTF-8 support. Rusty and Jon discuss topics such as decoding processes, properly formatted signatures, clear descriptions of payments, maximum field sizes, and the limitations of bech32.In another email, Jonathan Underwood shares code he used to make a payment request using UTF-8 descriptions. The results of the request are also provided in the email. Additionally, Jon proposes hiding text in the description under certain conditions and adding an "extra data" tag to test vectors to JSON encoding.Johan, a member of the Lightning-dev mailing list, suggests setting a reasonable maximum length for invoices that must be met. He believes this would simplify internal database logic and ensure fair error detection for all supported lengths. Johan agrees with UTF-8 support and up to 640 bytes length, but is unsure if 1023 is enough considering possibly multiple `r` tags and a juicy description. He also questions the description hash URL being part of the invoice as he always imagined this would be used between clients who had already agreed on payment for some kind of data, and that this hash would just ensure the correct payment.
